privacy_harms.harm_explanation: Linking Facebook caused the music app to broadcast a real-name notification ('Maria Silva is now on Friend Activity…') to all imported contacts. The data sender was the music app; data recipients included PTA parents, former classmates, and neighbors. This disclosure tied Maria's sex-work stage account to her legal identity, damaging her social and professional standing.

The un-prompted broadcast triggered immediate panic—Maria's racing heartbeat and fear of doxxing show acute anxiety caused by the system's exposure of her sensitive data (legal name and late-night activity) to people in her offline life.

The sidebar promised the app would 'never post,' yet it instantly pushed a real-name notification after Facebook sync. By breaking this promise, the app undermined Maria's choice about how her data would be shared.

Before she entered her credentials, the interface did not warn that a push notification would go to every synced contact. Withholding this crucial detail deprived Maria of the information needed for an informed decision.

Activating 'Private Session' could only stop future sharing; Maria had no way to retract or delete the broadcast already sent. This illustrates her powerlessness to prevent ongoing misuse of her personal data.
Publicly linking her real identity to sex-work content risks subscriber loss, payment-processor bans, and job discrimination—monetary harms stemming from the music app's disclosure.
Revealing Maria's legal name and nighttime presence increases doxxing and stalking risk. Such exposure can facilitate real-world assault against her or her child.
By exposing a Latina sex worker's legal identity, the app enables biased harassment and systemic disadvantages—entrenching inequality against a marginalized individual.
Maria was forced to unfollow a PTA parent to protect her child, fracturing trust within her school community. The unwanted link—created by Facebook sync—triggered this relationship damage.
